All Posts

Adding Redux to Svelte Apps

3 August 2022 · 10 minute read

svelte web

Svelte‚Äôs state management features only take you so far when your app increases in complexity. Redux solves this, but using it with Svelte isn‚Äôt the most established experience right now. In this post I‚Äôll be exploring using the two together.

üèÉ tl;dr: use the modules in this Gist to interact with Redux in Svelte like you would in React

Managing State Like a Purist

I picked up Svelte about a year ago at work, developing a new customer portal app. Being the new framework on the block, there aren‚Äôt reams of articles and StackOverflow answers for the things you try to Google, like ‚Äúsvelte state management how to‚Äù or ‚Äúsvelte complex state‚Äù.

Most of the results just pointed me at Svelte‚Äôs Context API and its Stores. As we‚Äôll explore, these tools are powerful primitives for building solutions for managing complicated state, but by themselves, it‚Äôs difficult to see how to.

For small-scale state that you want to communicate across your component hierarchy, they‚Äôre brilliant. Just create a writable store for one or a few values, and add it to context.

// ParentComponent.svelte

<script>
	const trafficLight: Writable<'green' | 'yellow' | 'red'> = writable('red');
	setContext('trafficLight', trafficLight);
</script>

// ChildComponent.svelte

<script>
	const trafficLight: Writable<'green' | 'yellow' | 'red'> = getContext('trafficLight');
  $: if ($trafficLight === 'green') {
    // GO!
  }
</script>

But this pattern only takes you so far. What do we do when we have multiple traffic lights that need synchronising? What if our traffic lights‚Äô states need to be fetched from an API?

These tools are just too basic for obvious patterns to jump out at you.

Exploring Redux

Facing this problem, I started looking into Redux. I didn‚Äôt know too much about it before this project, only that it‚Äôs a big player in frontend state management.

Surfing through the docs, I was surprised to discover how simple it is under the hood.

(Over-simplification trigger warning.)

Really, it‚Äôs just one huge object containing all of your state, ‚Äòthe store‚Äô. You attach listeners to the store, that are called whenever any part of it is updated. Using these listeners, you can update whatever you‚Äôre using to present the store‚Äôs data, whenever it changes. State is changed in pre-defined ways, identified by string keys called ‚Äòactions‚Äô, and enacted by functions called ‚Äòreducers‚Äô. You retrieve specific values from it using ‚Äôselectors‚Äô.

To people that know and use Redux, there‚Äôs much more to the experience than these fundamentals. The shape of your big state object needs to be carefully planned. Extensions called ‚Äòmiddlewares‚Äô are used to handle asynchronous state operations.

You also need to plug Redux into your frontend framework. Central to using Redux with React, for example, are the useSelector and useDispatch hooks, provided by the ‚Äòreact-redux‚Äô package.

useSelector returns a specific value from the store, that will automatically update whenever it‚Äôs changed within the store. These values are typically what you display in your components. useDispatch simply lets you dispatch actions to the store, which you‚Äôd hook up to a button click or whatever else.

Creating this sort of integration for Svelte is what we‚Äôll be exploring in this post. At the time of writing, I couldn‚Äôt find anything out there that gives me what these hooks do.

Using Redux in Svelte

I‚Äôm going to use a dummy to-do app that I‚Äôve thrown together using SvelteKit to demo all of this stuff (see SvelteKit‚Äôs ‚ÄòGetting Started‚Äô guide if you want to follow along).

Creating a Redux store with a handful of actions is easily done with the helpers provided by the official @reduxjs/toolkit package ‚Äî

// todos.ts

import { createSlice } from '@reduxjs/toolkit'
import type { PayloadAction } from '@reduxjs/toolkit'

type Todo = { id: string; text: string; done: boolean };
type TodosState = { todos: Todo[] };

export default createSlice({
  name: 'todos',
  initialState: { todos: [] },
  reducers: {
    add(state: TodosState, action: PayloadAction<string>) {
			// what you'd expect...
    },
    remove(state: TodosState, action: PayloadAction<string>) {
			// what you'd expect...
    },
    toggleDone(state: TodosState, action: PayloadAction<string>) {
			// what you'd expect...
    },
  },
})

// index.svelte

<script>
  import { configureStore } from '@reduxjs/toolkit';
  import todosSlice from '../todos';

  const store = configureStore({ reducer: todosSlice.reducer });
</script>

<!-- ... -->

In this snippet, we‚Äôre creating an instance of our Redux store in a component at the root of our app, index.svelte (have a read of SvelteKit‚Äôs docs if you‚Äôre scratching your head over this file‚Äôs name).

This createSlice function is a shortcut for creating a store (specifically, a portion, or ‚Äòslice‚Äô, of a store), its initial state, and some actions and reducer functions that operate on that state.

From here, we could just use our store‚Äôs dispatch, subscribe, and getState functions to access and update our state. These would be enough to give us a functioning app, but it would mean a lot of boilerplate in our components.

We want to build abstractions on top of these functions with Svelte‚Äôs tooling.

Turning a Redux into store a Svelte store

This beautiful Svelte REPL shows us how we modify our store‚Äôs subscribe method to meet the Svelte store contract. This means we can use Svelte‚Äôs auto-subscribe syntax to present the store‚Äôs data in our components.

We‚Äôre using Redux‚Äôs ‚Äòenhancers‚Äô feature to achieve this.

export default function svelteStoreEnhancer(
  createStoreApi: StoreCreator
): StoreEnhancerStoreCreator {
  return function (reducer, initialState) {
    const reduxStore = createStoreApi(reducer, initialState);
    return {
      ...reduxStore,
      subscribe(fn: ((value: any) => void)) {
        fn(reduxStore.getState());
        return reduxStore.subscribe(() => {
          fn(reduxStore.getState());
        });
      }
    }
  }
}

Including this enhancer in our configureStore call, gives us a Redux store that we can use like this ‚Äî

<ul>
  {#each $store.todos as todo}
    <li>
      <span>{todo.text}</span>
      <input type="checkbox" checked={todo.done}/>
    </li>
  {/each}
</ul>

This is feeling very Svelte-y already!

Remaking useSelector

Of course, we don‚Äôt want to be reading data from the store like this. We should be using selectors!

React-Redux‚Äôs useSelector hook produces a specific value from the store and subscribes it to updates. To recreate this using Svelte technology, we‚Äôll harness the power of derived stores. It‚Äôs easiest to just show you what this looks like.

let todos: Readable<Todo[]> = derived(
  store,
  ($store: TodosState) => $store.todos,
);

What we‚Äôre asking for here is a new store called todos, whose value is derived from the parent store through that lambda function. Whenever the parent store changes, todos is updated in turn with the new result from the lambda.

This lets us turn that {#each} loop above into just ‚Äî

{#each $todos as todo}
  <li>
    <span>{todo.text}</span>
    <input type="checkbox" checked={todo.done}/>
  </li>
{/each}

Using derived like this feels very similar to using useSelector ‚Äî we‚Äôre providing a selector function, and we‚Äôre getting back a reactive variable. We could write a simple wrapper function around this derived snippet called useSelector, and we‚Äôd basically have the same thing.

export type Selector<T, S> = (state: T) => S;

export function useSelector<T, S>(
  selector: Selector<T, S>,
  store: Readable<T>,
): Readable<S> {
  return derived(store, selector);
}

But we are having to provide a reference to our Redux store explicitly each time, something React‚Äôs useSelector doesn‚Äôt ask us to do. We can fix this by figuring out how to make our store ‚Äòglobally‚Äô available.

The <Provider/> Component

In React, we do this using the <Provider/> component, which makes its store prop available to everything beneath it in a component tree.

Sound familiar? Svelte‚Äôs context API! This is exactly what it was designed for. With it, we can easily recreate <Provider/> in Svelte, like so ‚Äî

<script lang="ts">
  import { setContext } from 'svelte';
  import type { Store } from '@reduxjs/toolkit';

  export let store: Store;

  setContext('STORE', store)
</script>

<slot/>

(We could just call setContext(...) directly in our root component, but let‚Äôs go full-React, why not.)

Remaking useSelector Properly

With our store tucked away in context, we can remove our useSelector implementation‚Äôs store parameter.

export function useSelector<T, S>(
  selector: Selector<T, S>
): Readable<S> {
  const store: Readable<T> = getContext('STORE');
  return derived(store, selector);
}

Using this in our to-do list component (I‚Äôve moved the to-do markup into its own component) ‚Äî

<script lang="ts">
  // ...
  let todos: Readable<Todo[]> = useSelector((store: TodosState) => store.todos);
</script>

<!-- ... -->

{#each $todos as todo}
  <Todo {todo}/>
{/each}

Beautiful!

But we‚Äôre ignoring one crucial piece of functionality of React‚Äôs useSelector: reacting only when the selected value changes.

Without it, any subscriptions for todos are going to be fired whenever any part of our entire store is updated. Obviously this isn‚Äôt a big deal for this example, but in the real world where stores are big and complicated, composed of multiple slices ‚Äî it is.

üí° Svelte does a fantastic job of making sure components are only re-rendered when they need to be. In the above example, each <Todo/> component is only re-created when the todo value changes, even if the object reference isn‚Äôt the same! It‚Äôs all a bit magic. Despite this, it‚Äôs important that the stores from useSelector only update when the selected value changes. This will minimise the work Svelte‚Äôs runtime has to do, and will mean any reactive statements involving these stores aren‚Äôt re-run unnecessarily.

Luckily, derived lets us give it a lambda function that conditionally updates the outputted store. Using this, we can change our useSelector function to call the given selector whenever the main store changes, compare the result to the previous value, and only update the derived store if there‚Äôs a difference.

export function useSelector<T, S>(
  selector: Selector<T, S>,
  equalityFn?: (lhs: S, rhs: S) => boolean,
): Readable<S> {
  equalityFn ||= (lhs: S, rhs: S) => lhs === rhs;

  const store: Readable<T> = getContext('STORE');
  let lastSelectorValue: S;

  return derived(
    store,
    ($state: T, set) => {
      const selectorValue: S = selector($state);
      if (!equalityFn(selectorValue, lastSelectorValue)) {
        lastSelectorValue = selectorValue;
        set(lastSelectorValue);
      }
    },
  );
}

Here, we‚Äôre accepting a set function in that lambda, which is what we use to update, or note update, the resultant store.

Just like React‚Äôs useSelector, ours offers an optional equalityFn parameter for non-trivial values.

Remaking useDispatch and useStore

I haven‚Äôt touched on the useStore hook yet. It‚Äôs just another function provided by the ‚Äòreact-redux‚Äô package that lets you access the store directly.

These two hooks are easy to make! All we‚Äôre doing is getting the store from context, and returning its dispatch property, or the store itself.

export function useDispatch<T>(): Dispatch {
  const store: Store<T> = getContext('STORE');
  return store.dispatch;
}

export function useStore<T>(): Store<T> {
  const store: Store<T> = getContext('STORE');
  return store;
}

Wrapping Up

That‚Äôs all there is to it! These functions could of course be improved to make them friendlier (throwing errors if the store isn‚Äôt in context, fancier type-aware default equalityFns, etc.), but they do the job.

Now we‚Äôre free to write Svelte applications with Redux like they were made for each other.

I‚Äôve put all of this code into a Gist if you‚Äôre wanting to copy and paste the lot into what you‚Äôre working on.

Thanks for reading!
